keyTakeAways: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old from Ichikawa, Japan, achieved a game-winning 38-yard field goal against Stanford during the NCAA college football season, becoming a global symbol of perseverance and self-education.
Matsuzawa learned football kicking through YouTube, imitating NFL players like Seattle Seahawks’ Jason Myers, and developed English skills through study and immersion in the U.S.
His journey includes overcoming personal setbacks, such as failing a college exam in Japan, and financial hardship, including waitressing and cutting his own hair to save money.
He received a scholarship to the University of Hawaii, funded by his parents’ sacrifices, and is now studying sports management.
Matsuzawa is inspired by Shohei Ohtani, a Japanese baseball superstar, and aspires to become the first Japanese national to play in the NFL.
Coach Thomas Sheffield played a pivotal role in bringing Matsuzawa to Hawaii and praised his journey as a testament to resilience, personal growth, and dedication.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old footballer from Ichikawa, Japan, achieved a dramatic game-winning 38-yard field goal against Stanford in the NCAA college football season, becoming a symbol of resilience and self-education. Having never learned to kick or speak English, Matsuzawa taught himself by watching YouTube videos of NFL players like Jason Myers and studied at Hocking College in Ohio to improve his English. Despite personal setbacks, including failing a college exam and financial hardship, he earned a scholarship to the University of Hawaii, where he now studies sports management. Inspired by Japanese baseball superstar Shohei Ohtani, Matsuzawa dreams of becoming the first Japanese national to play in the NFL, a goal that reflects both his personal journey and broader significance in global sports culture.
